laboratory_examinations.findings: The histopathologic examination revealed 38 Spitz nevi (SN) categorized into three groups: 20 (53%) classic SN (category I), 15 (39%) with atypical features (category II), and 3 (8%) as atypical Spitzoid neoplasms (ASN). Clinically assessed features varied from classic brown and dome-shaped SN to atypical nevi.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: The majority of the patients showed gradual development of new nevi without sudden increases in number. One patient initially diagnosed with category II SN developed 80 new nevi over 20 years.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Performed on two of the ASN which showed no chromosomal gains or losses.

Various biopsies showed a mixture of SN categories: classic SN, atypical nevi, and ASN across multiple patients. Specific lesions varied in size, with some noted at 4 mm, 5 mm, 6 mm, up to 12 mm in different clinical contexts.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Patients had biopsies at different intervals with no reported recurrence of lesions after initial biopsy or re-excision as per follow-up.
